instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No green no power
threads.message:
hello,

there was corrosion in the smc area. No voltage in <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. I checked the <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>, it's solid, could the 100k smc be dead?
I changed the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, the result is the same

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  8.17 volt
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> : 8.17 volt
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> : 16,5 volt
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.4 VOLT
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.4Volt
<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> : 3.0 volt
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : No voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No green no power
threads.message:
Start reballing SMC.
Must be done always when corrosion detected near it.

Then post all <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> voltages.
You can even compare its voltages before and after reballing.
Be sure all pads and traces under SMC are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No green no power
threads.message: I did smc reballing but the result did not change. Then I noticed that while <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> was reading 3.4 volts on pin2, it was 3 volts on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> pin3. When I checked, I saw that there was a break at the TP point. I made a connection from <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> to <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> pin3 and the green light came on, the device was turned on :)
